chargeHist.descr: Use a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime

result.execSummary:
The defendant Dennis P. Hagar was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Attempt Interfere w/ Custody-Beyond Visitation, a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.31(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: IMPOSED AND STAYED.  The defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program or the Earned Release Program.

superMiscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. Clerk of Courts shall docket without fees. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

No use or consumption of intoxicants.  No use or possession of controlled substances, unless prescribed by a physician.   No possession of drug paraphernalia.  Absolute sobriety.  No contact with children under 18 years without prior agent approval and an adult chaperone.  Defendant shall not enter any establishment in which their primary purpose is the sale of alcohol.

Complete compas assessment,  counseling, evaluations, programs and assessments as appropriate and followup.  Pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.  Submit DNA sample if not previously submitted.   Sex offender treatment and followup.  Assessment for cognitive or criminal thinking and followup.   Comply with Sex Offender Registry Program under 301.45, Wis. Stats.

supervisions.notes: SAME CONDITIONS AS CONDITION OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea
